questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder is trying to enable a skill in the developer console. The skill model builds without errors, but the Builder is unable to turn on testing.
What could be causing this?

choices.A: The skill's slot types are invalid.
choices.B: The skill does not have an example phrase
choices.D: The skill does not have an endpoint
choices.C: The skill does not have an invocation name

discussion.content:
https://developer.amazon.com/ja-JP/docs/alexa/devconsole/test-your-skill.html

The interaction model should include:

Specify the call name in Call Name> Skill Call Name.
In the intent, define one or more intents that contain sample utterances.
Defines the slot type (if the custom intent contains slots).
The model should be built without errors.

C

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder has published a skill to the Alexa Skills Store, but soon after realizes that Amazon Alexa is saying an incorrect word in one of the responses.
What is the recommended method for the Builder to correct this issue?

choices.C: Edit the response in a new endpoint, and after updating the In Development version of the skill, resubmit it for certification.
choices.A: Correct the response in a new endpoint, and after updating the In Development version of the skill, redeploy it.
choices.B: Access the In Development version of the skill, alter the intent that was causing the incorrect word, then resubmit the skill for certification.
choices.D: Correct the response in the existing endpoint of the Live version of the skill, then redeploy it.

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder needs to change the invocation name of a new skill.
What status should the skill be in to make this change?

discussion.content: B. Because the skill session ends when you send the Buy directive, be sure to save any relevant user data in a persistent data store so that your skill can continue where the user left off after the purchase flow is completed and your endpoint is back in control of the user experience. You can use any persistent storage you want. https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/docs/alexa/in-skill-purchase/add-isps-to-a-skill.html

choices.A: In a JSON file along with the skill's AWS Lambda function

questions.question_text:
An Amazon Alexa interactive story skill needs to provide users with the option to resume the skill from where users left off when they last used the skill.
Where should the data be stored to ensure that the skill will start at the correct location?

An Alexa Skill Builder is developing a skill that tells users facts about their neighborhoods using their postal codes. When running the skill, users receive error messages from their Amazon Alexa devices. When the Builder checks the logs, error messages are being sent when the device location API is used to get users' postal codes.
What are the potential causes of this issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I think A and C are the correct answers.
The answer is C and E.

choices.C: The users have opted out of giving their location information.
choices.A: The Alexa devices are registered in the incorrect postal code.
choices.E: The skill is not registered to access information in the developer console.
choices.D: The application ID of the skill does not match the expected application ID of the AWS Lambda function.
choices.B: The AWS Lambda function is not registered to the skill.

exam.name: AWS Certified Alexa Skill Builder - Specialty
